Use Excel to find the probability that the student gets more than 2 questions right, P(X > 2).
Guidance: Excel will calculate for us only probabilities of the type P(X = k) or P(X ≤ k). To find P(X > 2), think Complement Event.

To find P(X > 2) we notice that the complement rule of the event "X > 2" is X ≤ 2, and therefore P(X > 2) = 1 − P(X ≤ 2). In Excel, we'll use "=BINOMDIST(2, 10, 0.2, TRUE)", and we find that:
Binomial with n = 10 and p = 0.2
x P(X ≤ x) 2 0.6778
and therefore P(X > 2) = 1 − 0.6778 = 0.3222. There is about 32% chance that, using the guessing strategy, the student will get more than 2 questions right on the quiz.
